item.title: From National Statistics to Data Science
item.description: I’ve now been working in the Newcastle Data Science hub for a little over a month and I wanted to blog some personal reflections, in part for me to look back on my experience of moving in to a more digital role and for analysts considering getting in to data science but would like some insight in to the change they may experience. Having spent 2 and a half years working on publishing national statistics (whether in the form of bulletins or data on Stat-Xplore), it was time for me to try something new.

item.title: Aoife reports on the Use of R in Official Statistics conference
item.description: an image of the words “R in Official Statistics Conference”. The words are made up of an image of the hague and placed on a white background Introduction From the 12-14th September I attended the Use of R in Official Statistics (uRos) conference at The Hague, which 32 countries were represented at! I learnt so much over the 3 days, and meeting government statisticians from across the world who loved R was a really enriching experience.

item.title: About me
item.description: Originally from an ecology background, now a government statistician. My predominate coding language is R, but I’m hoping always looking to expand my technical knowledge, especially with open source software. I am particularly interested in how government can best use its data to inform citizens and improve services and can talk about these subjects for eons. On a more personal note, I’m a born and bred Londoner now living in Newcastle Upon Tyne.
